sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The War of 1812. Second War for Independence (1812-1815). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Daniel, age 16, militiaman from Baltimore, 1814.

I'm Daniel, sixteen, and we're at war with Britain again. The reasons are complicated: Britain's been stopping our ships, searching them, and forcing American sailors to serve in the British navy—"impressment," they call it. Britain aids Native tribes fighting American expansion. Americans want to seize Canada.
visuals: Chapter title: Going to War Again
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Daniel, sixteen, and we're at war with Britain again.

sections.narration: All night on September 13-14, 1814, British ships bombarded Fort McHenry. I watched from the city as "rockets' red glare" and "bombs bursting in air" lit up the darkness. Would the fort surrender? Could it hold?
sections.key_takeaway: All night on September 13-14, 1814, British ships bombarded Fort McHenry.

sections.narration:
August 1814 brought America's darkest moment in the war. A British force marched on Washington D.C., our nation's capital. Our militia tried to stop them at Bladensburg, Maryland, but we broke and ran—soldiers call it the "Bladensburg Races."

British troops entered Washington unopposed. They burned the Capitol building, where Congress meets.
visuals: Chapter title: The Burning of Washington
sections.key_takeaway: August 1814 brought America's darkest moment in the war.

sections.narration: Three months after we defended Baltimore, in December 1814, New England Federalists met in Hartford, Connecticut. They opposed the war from the beginning—it hurt their shipping trade with Britain. Some talked openly of New England leaving the Union. The Hartford Convention proposed constitutional amendments to limit federal power: require two-thirds vote to declare war, admit new states, or restrict trade.
sections.key_takeaway: Three months after we defended Baltimore, in December 1814, New England Federalists met in Hartford, Connecticut.

sections.section: Chapter 5: The Battle of New Orleans
sections.narration: The war's strangest moment came in January 1815. Andrew Jackson, commanding American forces in New Orleans, faced a battle British army. On January 8, British troops in neat formations charged American positions behind cotton bales and earthworks. It was a slaughter.
visuals: Chapter title: The Battle of New Orleans
sections.key_takeaway: The war's strangest moment came in January 1815.

sections.narration: The War of 1812 ended where it began—no territory changed hands, no major concessions made. Historians sometimes call it a pointless war, achieving nothing at the cost of thousands of lives. But it changed America in profound ways. First, it proved America's survival.
visuals: Chapter title: What the War Meant
sections.key_takeaway: The War of 1812 ended where it began—no territory changed hands, no major concessions made.
